DNS briefly i wish i had a diagram instead of this page passive DNS is a
way to collect transactions that are occurring in the domain name system between servers so there's a bunch of
recursive name servers that are being operated for us here by the black hat knock and who knows they're running
unbound or binders you know whatever they're running doesn't matter they're speaking a protocol that is causing our
laptops and smartphones to be able to surf and reach things because we're sending simple queries we're getting
back simple responses behind that server the recursive upstream of that recursive
server there's quite a bit more going on it's not just a simple one answer it should be 1 question 1 answer because
you may have to play go fish you might you know see if you're looking for dub dub dub example.com and you're you know
nothing you're going to have to have to ask the root servers where is calm you're going to have to have to ask the calm servers where is example.com and
finally you can ask the example.com servers where is dub dub dub but those
back-end transactions are the heart of passive DNS and certainly there's
different ways to do this my company happens to be in the passive DNS business but we're not the only ones
this is not a product pitch except to say that there's a way to do this that is quite compatible with the internet
neo libertarian philosophy of no surveillance and that is to say if you only gather upstream transactions that
are server to server sort of back office transactions you will have no subscriber IP addresses and you won't see any reuse
events you see no cache hits so you don't know what was popular and you don't know who looked it up and to me
that makes it pretty pretty passable I'm willing to of with this level of privacy intrusion
because there's no way to use our system for example to do surveillance you can't
start an investigation using only server-to-server traffic you might be able to enhance one but you could never
discover that a crime had taken place or get a suspect by looking at the data we
collect any case what you do with these observations is put them into a database
and you index them and if you do this long enough and you have enough servers
you will end up with a database that pretty accurately reflects the actual content of the entire DNS rather than
just the part of DNS that you yourself on your smartphone or laptop happen to have looked it looked up so in my
company we've been saving two hundred thousand events per second for about five years and we have I think a very
rich content source there and what you get to do with this after you index it
